nplcit.text: Yen-Liang Chen et al., "A data mining approach for retail knowledge discovery with consideration of the effect of shelf-space adjacency on sales," Elsevier, Decision Support Systems 42 (21 February 2006) 1503-1520

abstract.p: Articles such as compact discs are traded among a plurality of members who are registered in a common community. Each member has an account including a trading credit balance and a mailing address. A user interface is provided that allows a member to enter articles that the member owns and is willing to trade and articles that the member wants to own. The user interface also receives article trading instruction messages. An administration computer hosts the plurality of members and facilitates article trades among the members. The administration computer identifies matches between owned and wanted articles. For each identified match, an article trading instruction message is sent to the article owner requesting that the article owner mail the owned article to the mailing address of the member who wants to own the article. If the member sends the article, a trading credit is posted to the member's account and a trading debit and a monetary charge is posted to the member's account who will be receiving the article. Each traded article has the same trading credit. A priority algorithm is used to select the member who will receive the article if there is more than one member who wants an article that another member owns and is willing to trade. The priority algorithm is based in part on a member score that is a function of the relative value of the articles that a member owns and sends to another member compared to the relative value of the articles that the member wants and receives from another member, the relative value of the articles being determined by a demand for the article compared to a supply for the article among the members. A portion of the monetary charge is placed in a pool for distribution to the content creator of the article.

Articles such as compact discs are traded among a plurality of members who are registered in a common community. Each member has an account including a trading credit balance and a mailing address. A user interface is provided that allows a member to enter articles that the member owns and is willing to trade and articles that the member wants to own. The user interface also receives article trading instruction messages. An administration computer hosts the plurality of members and facilitates article trades among the members. The administration computer identifies matches between owned and wanted articles. For each identified match, an article trading instruction message is sent to the article owner requesting that the article owner mail the owned article to the mailing address of the member who wants to own the article.

If the member sends the article, a trading credit is posted to the member's account and a trading debit and a monetary charge is posted to the member's account who will be receiving the article. Each traded article has the same trading credit. A priority algorithm is used to select the member who will receive the article if there is more than one member who wants an article that another member owns and is willing to trade. The priority algorithm is based in part on a member score that is a function of the relative value of the articles that a member owns and sends to another member compared to the relative value of the articles that the member wants and receives from another member, the relative value of the articles being determined by a demand for the article compared to a supply for the article among the members.
A portion of the monetary charge is placed in a pool for distribution to the content creator of the article.

bibliographic-data.invention-title: Article trading among members of a community

abstract.p: Articles such as compact discs or electronic files are traded among a plurality of members who are registered in a common community. Each member has an account including a trading credit balance and a mailing address. A user interface is provided that allows a member to enter articles that the member owns and is willing to trade and articles that the member wants to own. The user interface also receives article trading instruction messages. An administration computer hosts the plurality of members and facilitates article trades among the members. The administration computer identifies matches between owned and wanted articles. A priority algorithm is used to select the member who will receive the article if there is more than one member who wants an article that another member owns and is willing to trade.

The priority algorithm is based in part on a member score that is a function of the relative value of the articles that a member owns and sends to another member compared to the relative value of the articles that the member wants and receives from another member, the relative value of the articles being determined by a demand for the article compared to a supply for the article among the members.

Articles such as compact discs are traded among a plurality of members who are registered in a common community. Each member has an account including a trading credit balance and a mailing address. A user interface is provided that allows a member to enter articles that the member owns and is willing to trade and articles that the member wants to own. The user interface also receives article trading instruction messages. An administration computer hosts the plurality of members and facilitates article trades among the members. The administration computer identifies matches between owned and wanted articles. For each identified match, an article trading instruction message is sent to the article owner requesting that the article owner mail the owned article to the mailing address of the member who wants to own the article. If the member sends the article, a trading credit is posted to the member's account and a trading debit and a monetary charge is posted to the member's account who will be receiving the article. Each traded article has the same trading credit. A priority algorithm is used to select the member who will receive the article if there is more than one member who wants an article that another member owns and is willing to trade. The priority algorithm is based in part on a member score that is a function of the relative value of the articles that a member owns and sends to another member compared to the relative value of the articles that the member wants and receives from another member, the relative value of the articles being determined by a demand for the article compared to a supply for the article among the members. A portion of the monetary charge is placed in a pool for distribution to the content creator of the article.

Articles such as compact discs are traded among a plurality of members who are registered in a common community. Each member has an account including a trading credit balance and a mailing address. A user interface is provided that allows a member to enter articles that the member owns and is willing to trade and articles that the member wants to own. The user interface also receives article trading instruction messages. An administration computer hosts the plurality of members and facilitates article trades among the members. The administration computer identifies matches between owned and wanted articles. For each identified match, an article trading instruction message is sent to the article owner requesting that the article owner mail the owned article to the mailing address of the member who wants to own the article.

If the member sends the article, a trading credit is posted to the member's account and a trading debit and a monetary charge is posted to the member's account who will be receiving the article. Each traded article has the same trading credit. A priority algorithm is used to select the member who will receive the article if there is more than one member who wants an article that another member owns and is willing to trade. The priority algorithm is based in part on a member score that is a function of the relative value of the articles that a member owns and sends to another member compared to the relative value of the articles that the member wants and receives from another member, the relative value of the articles being determined by a demand for the article compared to a supply for the article among the members.
A portion of the monetary charge is placed in a pool for distribution to the content creator of the article.

La présente invention concerne des articles tels que des disques compacts échangés entre une pluralité de membres inscrits à un club communautaire. Chaque membre dispose d'un compte qui comprend un solde de crédit d'échange et une adresse postale. Une interface d'utilisateur est fournie

elle permet à un membre de saisir les articles qui lui appartiennent et qu'il est disposé à échanger et ceux qu'il souhaite posséder. Cette interface d'utilisateur reçoit aussi des messages d'instruction d'échange d'articles. Un ordinateur d'administration héberge la pluralité des membres et facilite l'échange d'articles entre les membres. L'ordinateur d'administration identifie les correspondances entre articles possédés et articles voulus.

Pour chaque correspondance identifiée, un message d'instruction d'échange d'article est envoyé au propriétaire de l'article pour lui demander d'envoyer l'article qu'il possède à l'adresse postale du membre qui veut posséder cet article. Si le membre envoie l'article, un crédit d'échange est imputé à son compte et un débit d'échange et des frais sont imputés au compte du bénéficiaire de l'article. Chaque article échangé dispose du même crédit d'échange. Un algorithme de priorité est utilisé pour sélectionner le membre qui va recevoir l'article s'il existe plus d'un membre qui souhaite un article qu'un autre membre possède et qu'il est disposé à échanger.

Cet algorithme se base en partie sur le score d'un membre en fonction de la valeur relative des articles qu'un membre possède et envoie à un autre membre comparé à la valeur relative des articles que ce membre veut posséder et reçoit d'un autre membre, la valeur relative des articles étant déterminé par une demande pour cet article comparée à la disponibilité de cet article parmi les membres du club. Une portion des frais imputés est attribuée à une banque pour rétribuer le créateur du contenu de l'article.

Articles such as compact discs are traded among a plurality of members who are registered in a common community. Each member has an account including a trading credit balance and a mailing address. A user interface is provided that allows a member to enter articles that the member owns and is willing to trade and articles that the member wants to own. The user interface also receives article trading instruction messages. An administration computer hosts the plurality of members and facilitates article trades among the members. The administration computer identifies matches between owned and wanted articles. For each identified match, an article trading instruction message is sent to the article owner requesting that the article owner mail the owned article to the mailing address of the member who wants to own the article.

If the member sends the article, a trading credit is posted to the member's account and a trading debit and a monetary charge is posted to the member's account who will be receiving the article. Each traded article has the same trading credit. A priority algorithm is used to select the member who will receive the article if there is more than one member who wants an article that another member owns and is willing to trade. The priority algorithm is based in part on a member score that is a function of the relative value of the articles that a member owns and sends to another member compared to the relative value of the articles that the member wants and receives from another member, the relative value of the articles being determined by a demand for the article compared to a supply for the article among the members.
A portion of the monetary charge is placed in a pool for distribution to the content creator of the article.

La présente invention concerne des articles tels que des disques compacts échangés entre une pluralité de membres inscrits à un club communautaire. Chaque membre dispose d'un compte qui comprend un solde de crédit d'échange et une adresse postale. Une interface d'utilisateur est fournie

elle permet à un membre de saisir les articles qui lui appartiennent et qu'il est disposé à échanger et ceux qu'il souhaite posséder. Un ordinateur d'administration héberge la pluralité des membres et facilite l'échange d'articles entre les membres. Pour chaque correspondance identifiée, un message d'instruction d'échange d'article est envoyé au propriétaire de l'article pour lui demander d'envoyer l'article qu'il possède à l'adresse postale du membre qui veut posséder cet article. Si le membre envoie l'article, un crédit d'échange est imputé à son compte et un débit d'échange et des frais sont imputés au compte du bénéficiaire de l'article. Un algorithme de priorité est utilisé pour sélectionner le membre qui va recevoir l'article s'il existe plus d'un membre qui souhaite un article qu'un autre membre possède et qu'il est disposé à échanger.

Cet algorithme se base en partie sur le score d'un membre en fonction de la valeur relative des articles qu'un membre possède et envoie à un autre membre comparé à la valeur relative des articles que ce membre veut posséder et reçoit d'un autre membre, la valeur relative des articles étant déterminé par une demande pour cet article comparée à la disponibilité de cet article parmi les membres du club.
